section_purpose: To evaluate the transferability and generalization capabilities of ANYCSP models trained on specific CSP distributions when applied to different CSPs.
key_points: Each ANYCSP model performs best on the CSP distribution it was trained on.
There is significant compatibility between MODEL RB and graph coloring, with models trained on one solving instances of the other effectively.
The choice of aggregation function (MAX, MEAN, SUM) is crucial for generalization and performance across different CSPs.
The MAXCUT model is highly specialized and does not generalize to other problems, while no other models perform competitively on MAXCUT.
Generalization success depends on the similarity of instance distributions and the robustness of the aggregation functions used.

architectures: Aggregation functions: MAX, MEAN, SUM used in different models for processing inputs.
datasets: Structured Vertex Coloring instances (e.g., 1-FullIns_3_col, DSJC125.1, etc.)

dependencies: Section 4 Method (for model architecture and training)
Sections B.1 to B.5 (for context on datasets and evaluation metrics)
reproducibility_notes: Specific test datasets used for cross-comparison (listed in tables).
Evaluation metrics matching those from original experiments.
Aggregation functions used by each model (MAX for MODEL RB/graph coloring, MEAN for MAX-k-SAT, SUM for MAXCUT).
Software versions and URLs provided in Table 10 for comparison tools.
